title: Hey Riot Tantram
body:
I would like to discuss player behavior and moderation with you.

What's up?

replies.body:
> What's up?

Nm, what's up?

It is hard to know how personal to talk with a Rioter. I thought up some questions.

Is there anything new happening in the positive reinforcement genre? (Honor system and what have yous)

Who has the power to change player behavior systems at Riot?

Are you allowed to answer personal theology questions?

> Is there anything new happening in the positive reinforcement genre? (Honor system and what have yous)

Sportsmanship is the main focus for us. We have some cool stuff in the works, but I don't want to let the cat out of the bag on anything.

> Who has the power to change player behavior systems at Riot?

In what regard? My team, the Player Behavior team, is responsible for the policies and systems.

> Are you allowed to answer personal theology questions?

I don't see why not?

> [{quoted}](name=Riot Tantram,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=aIE85O17,comment-id=000000010000,timestamp=2017-01-18T01:59:21.671+0000)

> In what regard? My team, the Player Behavior team, is responsible for the policies and systems.


So you're the new behavior lead, replacing Lyte? Let me give you some advice. Some very serious, very real advice. There are three main things that have caused every behavior team prior to yours to fail, miserably. If you repeat their mistakes, you will effectively kill League of Legends, which is now at an all time low point thanks to the prior teams. So, here is what you should NOT do.

1 - Giving vague, generalized answers that do not answer the questions and concerns the community has. For example, this one:
http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/Boqd81O0-upcoming-upgrades-to-chat-restrictions?comment=00180000
This answer is vague and general. It answers nothing about the question that Starlighte asked. This is pretty normal for past behavior teams, and it drove people away. You look untrustworthy and incompetent when you can't even give the community a straight answer. Even something like "Unfortunately, quite a bit of the inner workings of our systems are confidential, and if I were to talk about it I could lose my position." would be a more acceptable answer than that.

2 - Embracing Orwellian safe spaces and political correctness. This was especially common during the rein of Lyte's behavior team. Here's another quote, again from Lyte's contemporary NeuroCat:
http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/Boqd81O0-upcoming-upgrades-to-chat-restrictions?comment=00070001
Tell me, how would you/do you justify this post? You really can't. Under Lyte, telling your jungler that he needs to gank more is effectively "offending the jungler" and worth a punishment. It doesn't matter how you tell him, what your wording is or how true the statement is. If the jungler says he's offended, then you're screwed. That is straight up Orwellian and that is the last thing you ever want to have in a video game, especially one where the entire game is based around two opposing teams competing on an objective based map. It's also how league has been since the end of season 3, to be absolutely honest.

3 - Most importantly, set your own standards and adhere to them. One of the biggest factors that led to the Tribunal being a complete and utter failure is Riot's decision to allow the community to set the standard for the Tribunal with no checks or balances. For the longest time, you could be banned for practically anything because the community was so varied. I distinctly remember very heated debates on the old forums centered around what exactly constitutes "verbal abuse". Some people think the word "Noob" is as bad as a racial slur, while others don't mind cursing as long as it's not actively aimed at others in a malicious manner. This community is NOT altruistic, and as the ones running the game it is in fact Riot's responsibility to use the thumb of god and actually make a definite and defined code of conduct, and expect players to adhere to it. Honestly, one of the first things you can do to work towards that is to expect players to use the mute button that everyone has access to and just mute players who are being toxic themselves. You need checks and balances, you need a standard and you need a code of conduct to compare behavior to. The current summoners code is a vague joke with no real meaning behind it.

If you can accomplish these three things, then you might be able to salvage this game. You might bring back a good chunk of the lost player base, and you might breathe much needed life into the community. Fail to do these things, and League of Legends will go the route of S2Games "Heroes of Newerth". Oh and I should probably mention, Riot has failed for about 5 years straight at this. Most players have gotten pretty wise to how Riot works, so people are going to be highly critical of you and not trust you. This is something you are going to have an especially hard time earning since, as I've mentioned, we've had to deal with this for 5 years straight. You are going to have to accept and admit to these failures if you want to earn anyone's trust, and really show that you do intend to fix the problems.

> So you're the new behavior lead, replacing Lyte?

No no no.

I'm the technical lead for the team. I take care of architecting and implementing systems.

> Giving vague, generalized answers that do not answer the questions and concerns the community has. For example, this one:
http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/Boqd81O0-upcoming-upgrades-to-chat-restrictions?comment=00180000 
This answer is vague and general. It answers nothing about the question that Starlighte asked. This is pretty normal for past behavior teams, and it drove people away. You look untrustworthy and incompetent when you can't even give the community a straight answer. Even something like "Unfortunately, quite a bit of the inner workings of our systems are confidential, and if I were to talk about it I could lose my position." would be a more acceptable answer than that.

I'll admit that it is sometimes difficult to be transparent about things. For example, people working on scripts may want to know more about script detection, so they can circumvent it. Obviously stating exactly how it works, while transparent, is not a good idea. In the post that you illustrated, Nerocat was trying to not giving away the 'exact' formula for reform so players could abuse system. We do know that this space needs to be addressed and we are currently thinking about ways to provide more account status transparency. For what it's worth, my commenting on your post is my attempt at being transparent.

> 2 - Embracing Orwellian safe spaces and political correctness. This was especially common during the rein of Lyte's behavior team. Here's another quote, again from Lyte's contemporary NeuroCat:
http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/Boqd81O0-upcoming-upgrades-to-chat-restrictions?comment=00070001 
Tell me, how would you/do you justify this post? You really can't.

Maybe you can tell me more about what you feel is inappropriate in the response. It's sort of a "treat others as you'd like to be treated" comment.

> 3 - Most importantly, set your own standards and adhere to them. One of the biggest factors that led to the Tribunal being a complete and utter failure is Riot's decision to allow the community to set the standard for the Tribunal with no checks or balances. For the longest time, you could be banned for practically anything because the community was so varied. I distinctly remember very heated debates on the old forums centered around what exactly constitutes "verbal abuse".

The Tribunal had problems, but this was not one of them. Believe it or not, the penalties were actually very accurate. The main problem the Tribunal had was throughput and time to resolution. A heated debate is great. It means people are passionate about their community. There were checks and balances. We would constantly review data, sample cases, monitor false positives/negatives, etc.

Thank you very much for the comment, Grandis. I always appreciate hearing the comments and views of others.

> [{quoted}](name=Riot Tantram,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=aIE85O17,comment-id=00000001000000010000,timestamp=2017-01-18T06:21:55.928+0000)
> I'll admit that it is sometimes difficult to be transparent about things. For example, people working on scripts may want to know more about script detection, so they can circumvent it. I'm going to put the quotes from Starlighte, NeuroCat and then Vermonster here. Starlighte and Vermonster asked very good questions, and properly addressed the terrible answer given by NeuroCat. This is a wonderful example of what is NOT an attempt at transparency. You can claim all day that you are "attempting to be transparent" but that does not make your actions or your methods attempts at transparency. The claim alone is irrelevant, the actions are what determine it's validity.

Starlighte first
> [{quoted}](name=Starlighte,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=Boqd81O0,comment-id=0018,timestamp=2015-09-15T20:10:32.445+0000)
>
> Let's talk a bit more about this specifically. You're saying, in an earlier response, that a player doesn't simply have 4 strikes. If they show genuine improvement, and have a temporary lapse months or even years later, that Riot isn't going to just pick up at whichever strike they left off at prior to reforming? So 2 chat restrictions in October 2015, won't mean that if you start being negative in August 2016, you'll get an instant suspension?

Now NeuroCat
> [{quoted}](name=Riot NeuroCat,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=Boqd81O0,comment-id=00180000,timestamp=2015-09-15T20:15:58.849+0000)
>
> We'll have systems in place to show appropriate consideration for players demonstrating long term, genuine reform.

And finally Vermonster
> [{quoted}](name=Vermonster,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=Boqd81O0,comment-id=001800000001,timestamp=2015-09-17T00:55:03.339+0000)
>
> You've said multiple times there will be a system in place but yet are vague and fail to describe any detail or time span on the system.  Care to enlighten us as to what this "appropriate consideration" is and what you consider "long term, genuine reform".  Your responses haven't really been helpful to understand what those mean.
> 
> Also, has Riot ever considered that perhaps the reporting options and bans have actually made the game more toxic?  I started playing season 1 and had no issues with league having a toxic environment.  Its only continued to become more and more toxic in game as you increase the strictness of your punishments and made reporting a mainstream option.  When a team starts asking the other team to report a player for feeding after they maybe make a bad play, they don't try and recover, often decided to just feed if they are getting reported anyways.  I see it over and over.  The toxic game environment is fed by your reporting and ban systems, and too often do I watch 2 or 3 players on my team or the other team (especially in ranked).  Team up on one player and all ask the other team to report them, or all say they are reporting that player and put that player into a complete rage.  Do those player ever get banned? The answer is no.  I have roughly 5 league accounts and from my oldest account to this account and through all the seasons I have seen how toxic the game actually is increase, while you claim your bans are causing the level of toxicity to decrease.  I don't see it on any of my accounts which range from pre-lvl 30 to Silver to Gold to one i use only for ranked teams.  
> 
> I will admit, I have been in every position of toxicity.  The one who causes players to go on tilt (and yet that player will get reported and I will get honors), the player who is harassed to no end by a group of teammates and is then reported after they ruined the game experience (it happens all the time, and you know that those responsible for making the game toxic get off scott free), and the silent bystander (90% of the time) who observes one or two teammates harass a player into a rage there that players game experience is ruined because maybe they took a position somebody else wanted, or made a mistake and gave first blood).
> 
> I hate to rain on Riots parade, but I don't think your systems have been working, and I don't think this new system is going to work.  Its going to end with the players who are easily flustered by others being toxic perma banned.  And the players who are creating the toxic environment continuing to ruin games, and pray upon other players while receiving no punishment.  
> 
> I'd love to hear what Riots view on this is, and whether you really think you're banning the right players.  Because I can tell you first hand, the times I have gotten chat restrictions, and bans, I was not the one creating a toxic playing environment, and the times that I have been the one creating the toxic environment, I have received nothing but honor, and other teammates or players on other teams immediately joining in and harassing players who likely will then get reported.

None of these questions have anything to do with scripts. Answering these questions does not harm the functionality of your system or it's security. If you won't answer these questions, you are not attempting transparency. You are simply demonstrating the same passive aggressive methodology of previous behavior teams. If you want to claim to be attempting transparency, you can start by answering these questions.


> Maybe you can tell me more about what you feel is inappropriate in the response. It's sort of a "treat others as you'd like to be treated" comment.

Certainly. 
1 - NeuroCat makes the claim that when you are talking with people over the internet they do not have the same context you do. That is already false, as you both have the same context within the game you are in. Context does not change between people in the same situation, only perception, but perception does not change the circumstances. 
2 - NeuroCat says "What you see as 'constructive advice' may come across to others as mean or insulting.". This is a logical fallacy because is insinuates that the advice is constructive or negative based on how the criticized perceives it. Take a match I played last night, we had a Fiddlesticks who repeatedly engaged the enemy Singed alone. He died every time he tried to do this, because singed is the single best counter to fiddle in the game (and because he was already ahead) and because Fiddle engaged him next to Singed's tower. I told him to stop engaging singed, to go farm and focus on other champs, I told him that singed was his direct counter, and that he was attacking him on singed's tower. I told him that all of these things put him at a massive disadvantage. Fiddle proceeded to get extremely offended that I didn't think he could fight singed and raged at everyone. Under NeuroCat's logic, Fiddle is in the right and I am in the wrong because my criticism, despite being "Constructive" is perceived by Fiddle as offensive regardless of circumstance surrounding it. It is impossible to deliver "Constructive criticism" under such a thought process because perception does not equal fact and anything can be considered offensive, especially because this process encourages players to engage in the thought process famously satirized in the Simpsons: "Am I out of touch? No, I can't be to blame. It's the children who are wrong".
3 - NeuroCat says "Properly framing feedback is a pretty useful skill not just in League, but in life." which is a loaded statement in the current situation. In real life, you are expected by your peers and co workers to pull your own weight. Properly framing feedback can be summed up in the phrase "Don't curse at people" however, in real life whether or not feedback is "properly framed" is determined by an unbiased and unattached third party. Properly framing feedback is then completely irrelevant in LoL since the one who determines what is "properly framing feedback" is the one being criticized.

All of these factors make this an inappropriate response to the question preceding it, which was Valenten asking: "Silly question but how with the new system determine if a person actually deserves a chat restriction. Cause I've been reported for actually giving constructive advice but was reported for what I would assume is "verbal abuse". This is a valid question, what stops people from simply "Being offended" by valid criticism? What stops people from simply refusing to accept criticism and just assert that everyone else is wrong BECAUSE I am right? How does this system differentiate between someone actually being verbally abusive, and someone just not wanting to take the advice or criticism? This is a great question, and it got a vague, deceptive and inappropriate response.



> The Tribunal had problems, but this was not one of them. Believe it or not, the penalties were actually very accurate. The main problem the Tribunal had was throughput and time to resolution. A heated debate is great. It means people are passionate about their community. There were checks and balances. We would constantly review data, sample cases, monitor false positives/negatives, etc.
> 
> Thank you very much for the comment, Grandis. I always appreciate hearing the comments and views of others.

I do not have room to write the response to this, so I will make a separate comment for it below.

>This is a logical fallacy because is insinuates that the advice is constructive or negative based on how the criticized perceives it.

Most of your problems seem to stem from the assumption that constructivity and negativity are mutually exclusive.

"omfg, buy some armor you fucking retards. Can't you morons see they're all AD?" is objectively constructive. It's also subjectively what I would consider to be negative and insulting.

Change it to "Can you guys please buy some fucking armor" and you can see how the subjective perception of what is being said becomes very important. If you, like me, like to very frequently use the F-bomb as a general method of putting emphasis on things, you might not intend this to be taken aggressively when you say it. But if somebody is only used to that word in the context of aggressivity, they will see it as an insult nonetheless.

And here's the thing: As frustrating as this might be to you, this is how communication works. Not online-communication, just communication in general. There is no objective truth when it comes to language, as all natural languages are ambiguous. As such pretty much everything is subject to interpretation... **especially** when it comes to whether or not something is insulting.

It's funny how you use that Simpsons quote and fail to apply it to yourself. If people understand everything you say as an insult even though you are not intending it to be, then you are the one who is out of touch with the rest of the world.

If the entire world decided simultaneously to call the color green "red", and the color red "green", then you can either insist that you are in the right and keep on miscommunicating with every single person you meet, or you can start calling colors by the same "incorrect" names.

A lot of people get upset way too quickly, while putting too little thought into whether or not a person actually meant to insult them. But that's no excuse to put equally little thought into how your words will be perceived by the person you're talking to.

That's all Neurocat was trying to say. Think about how your words are perceived by others, instead of shifting the blame to the people that misunderstand you.

> That's all Neurocat was trying to say. Think about how your words are perceived by others, instead of shifting the blame to the people that misunderstand you.

I would add that this is especially important when you're only communicating through text.  Face to face a huge amount of our understanding of a conversation is conveyed through body language and vocal tone, something we don't have at all with just text.

Oh yes... the amount of times I've witnessed chat communication escalate between people that in real life get along perfectly well is too damn high. Happens even when only body language is missing, e.g. on Skype/TS.

The number of times I've had to later clarify things with my mom or sister after a text message conversation...

People underestimate how important body language is for understanding.  My nephew has Aspergers and we have to be very careful about sarcasm or joking with him because he just doesn't understand it.

> [{quoted}](name=TrulyBland,realm=EUNE,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=aIE85O17,comment-id=0000000100000001000000000001,timestamp=2017-01-18T18:18:21.004+0000)
>
> Most of your problems seem to stem from the assumption that constructivity and negativity are mutually exclusive.
> 
> "omfg, buy some armor you fucking retards. Can't you morons see they're all AD?" is objectively constructive. It's also subjectively what I would consider to be negative and insulting.
> 
> Change it to "Can you guys please buy some fucking armor" and you can see how the subjective perception of what is being said becomes very important. If you, like me, like to very frequently use the F-bomb as a general method of putting emphasis on things, you might not intend this to be taken aggressively when you say it. But if somebody is only used to that word in the context of aggressivity, they will see it as an insult nonetheless.

No, my issue is that the current system definition according to the current system is not set, making it change drastically based on the perception of the individual being criticized, lumps everything into the same level of alleged "negativity" and assumes that no one can be an adult. 
Let's look at your example, and then factor it into the way I view it. "omfg buy some armor you fucking retards. Can't you morons see they're all AD?". He could have worded it nicer, but I would say this is not ban worthy. It's not excessive, if someone doesn't like it they can mute him themselves and if they can see this anyway then they willingly disabled the language filter. The game is rated T for Teen, I expect people to be aware of that coming in. Is it constructive? Yes, if the enemy team is all AD then armor is invaluable. If the team is building magic resistance against an all AD team, they are making bad decisions. The subjective perception being there at all is WHY I have an issue with this, a MUCH better method proven by many, many different companies over the years doing it, would be for Riot to make a definitive and concrete list of things you can be banned for, and sticking to it. One of the most important things that keeps these companies communities strong is the company not infantalizing their communities. Allowing the perception of the accused to be the rule and not the exception does in fact create nothing than make the most powerful argument "Well that offends me in particular".

> And here's the thing: As frustrating as this might be to you, this is how communication works. Not online-communication, just communication in general. There is no objective truth when it comes to language, as all natural languages are ambiguous. As such pretty much everything is subject to interpretation... **especially** when it comes to whether or not something is insulting.

There is objective truth when it comes to language, in written or spoken. Sarcasm may be harder to grasp, because that is a communication tool that relies on emotion. When dealing with written communication, the problems only start when you start trying to perceive more than what is there. Take the examples "Initiate please" and "INITIATE PLEASE". These are distinctly different because one has emphasis and one does not. That is the only difference, they still mean the same thing. This is objective truth, subjectivity has to be injected by people trying to create or add meaning that was not there before.

> It's funny how you use that Simpsons quote and fail to apply it to yourself. If people understand everything you say as an insult even though you are not intending it to be, then you are the one who is out of touch with the rest of the world.
> 
> If the entire world decided simultaneously to call the color green "red", and the color red "green", then you can either insist that you are in the right and keep on miscommunicating with every single person you meet, or you can start calling colors by the same "incorrect" names.

Both of these are logical fallacies. First, you are begging the question. You've provided the conclusion of the argument as a premise. You are not proving how I have "failed to apply to it myself" just claiming that is the sole argument. Second, you've used the bandwagon argument. Just because a bunch of people all take the color "red" and call it "green" does not change objective facts that red is red and green is green. Agreeing with a bunch of people who are wrong makes you just as wrong.

> A lot of people get upset way too quickly, while putting too little thought into whether or not a person actually meant to insult them. But that's no excuse to put equally little thought into how your words will be perceived by the person you're talking to.
> 
> That's all Neurocat was trying to say. Think about how your words are perceived by others, instead of shifting the blame to the people that misunderstand you.


No, NeuroCat was dodging the question. Neurocats answer in no way, shape or form addressed or answered the question that was asked. I even quoted the question verbatim.

>There is objective truth when it comes to language

Okay, what's the objective truth about this sentence:
"I was watching the man with the binoculars".
What does this sentence objectively and truthfully describe?

>Just because a bunch of people all take the color "red" and call it "green" does not change objective facts that red is red and green is green. Agreeing with a bunch of people who are wrong makes you just as wrong.

And as I explained, you can keep on insisting that you are right and literally fail to communicate with every single other person. Okay, you're right, great. But you are intentionally using words that you **know** will lead them to the wrong conclusions.

If you choose to be "right" over choosing to be understood, you are failing at the core principle of communication.

And thanks for supporting my argument indirectly with this bit:

>No, NeuroCat was dodging the question. Neurocats answer in no way, shape or form addressed or answered the question that was asked. 

To me that answer is an absolutely fine answer to that question. You don't seem to think so. The impression we both get from the same two bits of text gives us entirely different ideas about the intention of NeuroCat's post. And the funny thing is, that ultimately I'd agree with you that NeuroCat's post was bad.
A lot of people downvoted his post, which likely means that regardless of what he **meant** to say, people didn't understand him. And since making people understand his replies to questions is part of his job, that means he failed at his job, regardless of what he intended to convey.

> [{quoted}](name=TrulyBland,realm=EUNE,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=aIE85O17,comment-id=000000010000000100000000000100010000,timestamp=2017-01-19T04:26:58.096+0000)
>
> Okay, what's the objective truth about this sentence:
> "I was watching the man with the binoculars".
> What does this sentence objectively and truthfully describe?
> 

What is objectively true about this sentence is that the individual known as "I" was watching another specific man who had binoculars. It is objective that the sentence structure supports this, as if "I" was using binoculars to watch the specific man, the sentence structure would be "I was watching the man, with the binoculars." It truthfully describes "I" observing another man, who is in possession of binoculars. Nothing else is provided, and as such nothing else exists unless someone adds more meaning or content to the sentence.

> And as I explained, you can keep on insisting that you are right and literally fail to communicate with every single other person. Okay, you're right, great. But you are intentionally using words that you **know** will lead them to the wrong conclusions.
> 
> If you choose to be "right" over choosing to be understood, you are failing at the core principle of communication.

Again, incorrect. Agreeing with a bunch of people who are wrong does not change the fact that they are wrong. If they want to provide some evidence to support a claim such as "At some point in the past, the colors "Red" and "Green" had their names switched, so what we have been calling "Red" is actually "Green" and vice versa" then this would be a statement that can be objectively analyzed and researched. The problem is that you are ignoring evidence, I am not "Insisting" that I am right, I am "proving" that I am right. I provide evidence to support my claim, which IS in opposition to your claim, and you simply then use the argument "well all my friends say you're wrong, so you're wrong". Tell me, if my claim is "jumping off the grand canyon will kill you" and this is supported by the combination of factors including distance, velocity, and gravity resulting in your body being subjected to massive blunt force trauma, and the extremely hard and sharp rocky cliff face will rip, tear and penetrate your body on the way down, resulting in death, but a bunch of other people say "You can't die jumping off the grand canyon" are you going to ignore the various objective facts about the human body and believe them? You can ignore the evidence all you want, but I sincerely doubt you are going to go and jump off the grand canyon in real life. So, why are you jumping off the grand canyon intellectually?

> 
> And thanks for supporting my argument indirectly with this bit:
> 
> To me that answer is an absolutely fine answer to that question. You don't seem to think so. The impression we both get from the same two bits of text gives us entirely different ideas about the intention of NeuroCat's post. And the funny thing is, that ultimately I'd agree with you that NeuroCat's post was bad.
> A lot of people downvoted his post, which likely means that regardless of what he **meant** to say, people didn't understand him. And since making people understand his replies to questions is part of his job, that means he failed at his job, regardless of what he intended to convey.

The difference here is you trust Riot, and I don't. I see questions people asked, and I see them being dodged. I can demonstrate how they are being dodged and I am arguing for answers. You are arguing to just trust Riot.

First off: I'm about 99% certain the comma is not necessary. I'm also 100% certain that such ambiguities exist in German. The point is: Natural languages have ambiguities in them. That's a fact.

Secondly: You keep arguing about who is right, and I keep telling you that who is right is irrelevant. Proving or insisting, you are talking to people in a language they don't understand. Worse even, you are talking to people in a language they **misunderstand**. And if you do that despite knowing that you will be misunderstood you are in idiot.

Your analogy with the grand canyon has literally nothing to do with anything I said. This isn't about whether or not the statements are true, but whether or not the words people use are "correct". You are nonstop mixing up concepts and the words used to describe these concepts.

There is the concept of a color, a specific wavelength of light. And the other side there is the word we use to convey this concept, to make others understand what concept we are thinking of.
You can either choose to convey the correct concept, or use the "correct" word. But again: Words are **meant** to convey concepts. If you prefer to use a certain word, rather than conveying a certain concept, you are not using words for the only purpose they have.

>The difference here is you trust Riot, and I don't.

No. The difference is that I can shift my point of view and actually **try** to understand that reply. Something you obviously cannot do if you believe in a "correct" way to interpret and understand language.

Case in point:

>I can demonstrate how they are being dodged.

You cannot. Because I see the answer to the question that was asked in that post. You don't, and that's fine. But you cannot argue that the way I understand answer and question does not exist based on the way you understand them.
Your way of understanding things is not the only way.

Seriously, this is delving way deeper into philosophy than I original intended, but please, for your own sake, try to see the world through other peoples' eyes some time. I've never seen anybody quite as solipsistic as you.

> [{quoted}](name=TrulyBland,realm=EUNE,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=aIE85O17,comment-id=00000001000000010000000000010001000000000000,timestamp=2017-01-19T17:20:37.442+0000)
>
> First off: I'm about 99% certain the comma is not necessary. I'm also 100% certain that such ambiguities exist in German. The point is: Natural languages have ambiguities in them. That's a fact.

Allow me to demonstrate why the comma is necessary in only two words, and that you do not understand grammar.
"Yes daddy" vs "yes, daddy".
